verses.text: It was told to Joab, "Look, the king is weeping and mourning for Absalom."
verses.comment: Direct translation from Hebrew; conveys the report to Joab.

verses.text: So the victory that day was turned into mourning for all the people, because the people heard it said that day, "The king is grieving for his son."
verses.comment: Captures how the day's mood changed among the people.

verses.text: And the people stole into the city that day, like people who are ashamed when they flee in battle.
verses.comment: The word 'stole' means they entered quietly or secretly.

verses.text: The king covered his face, and the king cried out with a loud voice, "My son Absalom! Absalom, my son, my son!"
verses.comment: Direct quote; preserves the Hebrew repetition for mourning.

verses.text: Joab came into the house to the king and said, "Today you have shamed the faces of all your servants, who have saved your life, the lives of your sons and daughters, the lives of your wives, and the lives of your concubines,
verses.comment: Listing those whom the servants saved, as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: because you love those who hate you and hate those who love you. You have made it clear today that commanders and servants mean nothing to you. For today I see that if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead, you would be pleased.
verses.comment: Preserves Joab’s rebuke in clear language.

verses.text: Now therefore, arise, go out and speak kindly to your servants. For I swear by the Lord, if you do not go out, not a man will stay with you tonight, and this will be worse for you than all the trouble that has come upon you from your youth until now."
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew structure; Joab’s oath is included.

verses.text: So the king arose and sat in the gate. And all the people were told, "Look, the king is sitting in the gate." Then all the people came before the king. Now Israel had fled, every man to his tent.
verses.comment: "Israel" here refers to the followers of Absalom.

verses.text: All the people throughout all the tribes of Israel argued, saying, "The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies, he saved us from the hand of the Philistines, and now he has fled out of the land because of Absalom.
verses.comment: Captures the reason for debate among the tribes.

verses.text: And Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. So now, why do you say nothing about bringing the king back?"
verses.comment: Conveys the people's call for David’s restoration.

verses.text: King David sent a message to Zadok and Abiathar the priests, saying, "Speak to the elders of Judah, and say, 'Why should you be the last to bring the king back to his palace, since the talk of all Israel has come to the king at his house?
verses.comment: Restates David’s effort to restore unity.

verses.text: You are my brothers; you are my bone and my flesh. Why then should you be the last to bring back the king?'"
verses.comment: Direct address to Judah’s leaders as family.

verses.text: And say to Amasa, 'Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do so to me and more also, if you are not commander of the army before me continually, in place of Joab.'"
verses.comment: David’s oath just as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: He won over the heart of all the men of Judah, as one man, so that they sent word to the king, "Return, you and all your servants."
verses.comment: ‘As one man’ means unanimous agreement, literal from Hebrew.

verses.text: So the king returned and came to the Jordan. And the men of Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king, to bring the king across the Jordan.
verses.comment: Faithful to the original sequence and location.

verses.text: And Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
verses.comment: Clarifies Shimei’s identity and intentions.

verses.text: With him were a thousand men from Benjamin. And Ziba the servant of the house of Saul, and his fifteen sons and twenty servants with him, rushed down to the Jordan before the king.
verses.comment: Lists the people present with Shimei.

verses.text: They crossed the ford to bring over the king's household, and to do what pleased him. Shimei the son of Gera fell down before the king, as he was about to cross the Jordan,
verses.comment: Preserves the sense of urgency and humility in the original.

verses.text: and said to the king, "Do not let my lord hold me guilty or remember how your servant did wrong the day my lord the king left Jerusalem. Please do not let the king take it to heart.
verses.comment: Shimei’s plea for forgiveness.

verses.text: For your servant knows that I have sinned. Therefore, I have come this day, first of all the house of Joseph, to come down and meet my lord the king."
verses.comment: The phrase 'house of Joseph' represents the northern tribes.

verses.text: Abishai the son of Zeruiah answered, "Should not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the Lord's anointed?"
verses.comment: The Lord's anointed refers to David as God's chosen king.

verses.text: But David said, "What have I to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah, that you would be an adversary to me today? Should any man be put to death in Israel today? For do I not know that I am king over Israel today?"
verses.comment: Captures David's tone of mercy and his rhetorical questions.

verses.text: So the king said to Shimei, "You shall not die." And the king gave him his oath.
verses.comment: Confirms David’s act of pardon.

verses.text: Now Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king. He had not cared for his feet, trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes from the day the king departed until he returned in peace.
verses.comment: Describes Mephibosheth's visible acts of mourning.

verses.text: When he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him, "Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?"
verses.comment: Replicates David’s direct address.

verses.text: He answered, "My lord the king, my servant deceived me. For your servant said, 'Saddle a donkey for me, that I may ride on it and go with the king,' for your servant is lame.
verses.comment: Stays true to the detail of Mephibosheth’s explanation.

verses.text: He slandered your servant to my lord the king. But my lord the king is like an angel of God; therefore, do what seems good to you.
verses.comment: Echoes Mephibosheth’s confidence in David’s justice.

verses.text: For all my father’s house were but dead men before my lord the king; yet you set your servant among those who eat at your own table. What right have I to cry out anymore to the king?"
verses.comment: Highlights Mephibosheth’s humility and gratitude.

verses.text: So the king said to him, "Why speak any more of your affairs? I have decided: You and Ziba shall divide the land."
verses.comment: Replicates David’s resolution.

verses.text: Mephibosheth said to the king, "Let him even take it all, since my lord the king has come safely back to his own house."
verses.comment: Demonstrates Mephibosheth’s loyalty toward David.

verses.text: Barzillai the Gileadite had come down from Rogelim, and he went on with the king to the Jordan to escort him over the Jordan.
verses.comment: Mentions Barzillai's assistance to David.

verses.text: Barzillai was a very old man, eighty years old. He had provided for the king while he stayed at Mahanaim, for he was a very wealthy man.
verses.comment: Faithful to details about Barzillai’s aid.

verses.text: The king said to Barzillai, "Come over with me, and I will provide for you with me in Jerusalem."
verses.comment: David’s generous offer to Barzillai.

verses.text: But Barzillai said to the king, "How many years have I still to live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
verses.comment: Barzillai humbly questions the point of moving at his age.

verses.text: I am this day eighty years old. Can I know what is good or bad? Can your servant taste what he eats or what he drinks? Can I still hear the voice of singing men and women? Why then should your servant be a burden to my lord the king?
verses.comment: Barzillai highlights the limitations of old age.

verses.text: Your servant will go a little way over the Jordan with the king. Why should the king repay me with such a reward?
verses.comment: Barzillai humbly declines riches.

verses.text: Please let your servant return, that I may die in my own city, near the grave of my father and mother. But here is your servant Chimham. Let him go over with my lord the king, and do for him whatever seems good to you."
verses.comment: Chimham is likely Barzillai’s son or close relation.

verses.text: The king answered, "Chimham shall go over with me, and I will do for him whatever seems good to you. And whatever you desire of me, I will do for you."
verses.comment: David honors Barzillai’s request.

verses.text: All the people crossed the Jordan, and the king crossed. The king kissed Barzillai and blessed him, and he returned to his own place.
verses.comment: A public display of affection and honor.

verses.text: Then the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him. All the people of Judah, and also half the people of Israel, brought the king on his way.
verses.comment: Shows the partial national support for David.

verses.text: Look, all the men of Israel came to the king and said to him, "Why have our brothers the men of Judah stolen you away, and brought the king, his household, and all David’s men with him over the Jordan?"
verses.comment: Represents trans-tribal tension over David’s return.

verses.text: All the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, "Because the king is our close relative. Why then are you angry over this matter? Have we eaten at the king’s expense, or has he given us any gift?"
verses.comment: Judah defends their loyalty and motives.

verses.text: The men of Israel answered the men of Judah, "We have ten shares in the king, and therefore we have more right in David than you. Why then did you despise us, that our advice was not the first in bringing back our king?" But the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the words of the men of Israel.
verses.comment: Conveys the division and tension between Israel and Judah. The 'ten shares' refers to the ten northern tribes.
